3.learning_goal: Object-Oriented Foundations: In this unit, students will learn to think in objects by defining Python classes, creating and using multiple instances with their own state and behavior, distinguishing identity, equality, and mutability, working with class-level attributes and built-in modules, and writing constructors and methods (using self) to model and solve simple real-world problems.

chapters.title: Introduction to Object-Oriented Thinking
chapters.learning_goals: Learn the core ideas of object-oriented programming—objects, classes, instances, identity vs equality—and practice modeling real-world concepts as objects with state and behavior using simple scripts.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Welcome to OOP!
lessons.learning_outcomes: Understand the course main topics and grading

lessons.title: What is OOP and why do we need it?
lessons.learning_outcomes: Understand why different programming paradigms exist.; Identify Object-Oriented Programming as a paradigm; Understand why Object-Oriented Programming is used based on real-world examples

lessons.title: Objects = data + behavior
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify an object as an entity that combines data attributes (state) and behavior (actions).; Distinguish between the state and behavior of real-world objects.

lessons.title: Classes and instances
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify a class as a blueprint that defines shared structure and behavior.; Understand what a class instance is and that multiple instances can be created from the same class.; Recognize basic CaptialCase convention for Class names.

lessons.title: Object identity vs equality
lessons.learning_outcomes: Distinguish between two variables pointing to the same object and two objects having the same value.; Explain why identity vs equality matters when working with object state.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Cafe items as objects
lessons.learning_outcomes: Model simple real-world items as objects by separating their state (data) and behavior (actions). Output: A script that prints information about cafe menu items and simulates simple actions like “serve” or “discount” using object-like structures.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Library books identity vs equality
lessons.learning_outcomes: Differentiate between object identity and equality by comparing multiple “book” records that may share the same data but not the same identity. Output: A script that creates several book variables and prints whether they are the same object or just have the same values.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Music playlist classes and instances
lessons.learning_outcomes: Recognize a class as a blueprint and create multiple instances to represent different songs in a playlist. Output: A script that defines a Song class and prints details for several Song instances to show they share structure but hold different data.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: To-do tasks as objects
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify objects as combinations of data and behavior by designing a simple Task concept with state and actions. Output: A script that represents several to-do tasks and prints their state changes when “completed” or “postponed.”

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Objects, Mutability, and Modules
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how Python objects behave in memory, including the difference between mutable and immutable types, and how to use class attributes and methods for shared configuration. Practice importing and using built-in modules to create and interact with objects, culminating in small hands-on projects like dice rollers and lottery generators.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Mutable vs immutable, why it matters
lessons.learning_outcomes: Understand the necessity of mutability & immutability objects.; Identify common mutable types and common immutable types in Python.

lessons.title: Class-level basics: attributes & methods
lessons.learning_outcomes: Identify a class attribute as shared data stored on the class.; Recognize a class method as behavior called on the class .

lessons.title: Quick detour: built-in modules
lessons.learning_outcomes: Recognize a module as a collection of related Python code.; Use an import statement to access basic code from a built-in module.

lessons.title: Objects in action
lessons.learning_outcomes: Recognize that calling Random() with parenthesis, creates an object (instance) from a class.; Understand that the object's actions are called and use methods on a Random object to trigger behavior and produce data.; Distinguish between the object itself, its methods, and the data produced by those methods.

lessons.title: Challenge
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply learned OOP concepts to complete a small challenge and summarize key takeaways

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Shopping cart mutability
lessons.learning_outcomes: Distinguish between mutable and immutable objects by experimenting with adding, removing, and replacing items in a shopping cart scenario. Output: A script that shows how changing a list of items affects shared references while strings and numbers remain unchanged.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Game settings as class attributes
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use class attributes and class methods to represent shared configuration for a simple game. Output: A script that defines a GameSettings class with shared difficulty and theme, then prints and updates these values through the class.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Dice roller with random module
lessons.learning_outcomes: Import and use a built-in module to create and interact with an object, distinguishing between the object, its methods, and the data it returns. Output: A script that uses random.Random to roll virtual dice multiple times and prints the results.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Lottery picker challenge
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply mutability concepts, class-level basics, and built-in modules to design a small lottery-number generator. Output: A script that uses a Random object and possibly class-level configuration to generate and print a set of “lottery” numbers.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: First Steps with Python Classes
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to think in objects and use Python classes to model simple real‑world entities. Practice defining classes, creating multiple independent objects, and writing basic methods that use `self` to access and modify an object’s data.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Review: thinking in objects
lessons.learning_outcomes: Review and consolidate understanding of objects, classes, and basic OOP terminology; Reflect on how to model simple problems using objects

lessons.title: Creating your first class
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ability to define a minimal Python class using the class keyword without providing an __init__ method.; Ability to create objects from a basic class, inspect it's type, and assign attributes to those objects after instantiation.; Ability to diffrentiate between class definition and instantiation, prefereably using comments in code

lessons.title: Creating multiple objects from one class
lessons.learning_outcomes: Understand that each object created from a class maintains its own independent set of attribute values.; Ability to create a class from scratch, and then instantiate two more objects from it and assign different attribute values.; Ability to seperate between the variable name (the one that holds the instance) and the attributes inside an instance.

lessons.title: Methods: the role of self
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ability to define a class method with self as the first parameter (without exploring its meaning yet).; Understand `self` as a reference to the current object, used by methods to access its data and behavior.; Create an object and call its instance methods using dot notation to trigger behavior.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Recipe card class
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define a minimal class and create objects from it while clearly separating the class definition from instantiation. Output: A script that defines a Recipe class and then creates and prints several recipe objects with attributes assigned after creation.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Pet records multiple instances
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create multiple objects from a single class and give each instance independent attribute values. Output: A script that defines a Pet class, creates several Pet objects, and prints their different names, species, and ages.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Library members and thinking in objects
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice “thinking in objects” by modeling library members and their basic properties using classes and instances. Output: A script that defines a Member class and prints a simple summary for several member objects to show how the model maps to the real world.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Fitness tracker methods and self
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use instance methods with self to access and display an object’s data. Output: A script that defines a WorkoutSession class with methods that use self to print details like duration and calories burned.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Bank account methods self in action
lessons.learning_outcomes: Call instance methods that rely on self to read and modify an object’s own attributes. Output: A script that defines a BankAccount class whose methods (like deposit and withdraw) update and print the account balance for each separate account object.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Building and Initializing Python Objects
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how to define Python classes with instance methods and constructors, use `self` and attributes to model real-world entities, and create interacting objects through practical, small applications.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Self param, and methods that use attributes
lessons.learning_outcomes: Understand the meaning of the self param; Ability to write an instance method that accesses attributes via self to produce output such as printing a stored name.; Capability to reason about how changes to object attributes affect the behavior of instance methods that reference those attributes.

lessons.title: Challenge I
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ability to compose a small Python program that defines and uses classes and objects, representing real life entities.; Capability to trace how objects created from different classes interact through method calls and attribute access in a simple application.

lessons.title: Constructors: where objects begin
lessons.learning_outcomes: Understand the __init__ syntax, and the idea of a constructor; Recognize that __init__ runs automatically when an object is created.

lessons.title: Constructors with inputs
lessons.learning_outcomes: Write an __init__ method that receives parameters and assigns them to attributes.; Instantiate objects by passing arguments to the constructor.; Understand that required constructor parameters must be provided.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Contact book self and attributes
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use self in instance methods to access and present stored attributes such as a person’s name and phone number. Output: A script that defines a Contact class and prints formatted contact details using methods that rely on self.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Movie tickets app challenge
lessons.learning_outcomes: Combine multiple classes and objects to simulate simple interactions in a movie ticket scenario. Output: A script that defines classes such as Movie and Ticket, creates objects from them, and prints how a user “buys” or “views” tickets.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Habit tracker constructor basics
lessons.learning_outcomes: Implement a basic __init__ constructor that runs automatically to set up new objects. Output: A script that defines a Habit class whose constructor initializes attributes like name and frequency, then prints them for several Habit objects.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Food delivery order constructor inputs - Part 1
lessons.learning_outcomes: Write a constructor that accepts input parameters and assigns them to attributes for a simple order model. Output: A script that defines an Order class with an __init__ that receives values such as item, quantity, and address, then prints each order’s details.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Food delivery order constructor inputs - Part 2
lessons.learning_outcomes: Instantiate multiple objects by passing different arguments to the constructor and reason about required parameters. Output: A script that creates several Order objects with varied constructor inputs and prints confirmations showing each order’s specific data.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Weekly Review
chapters.learning_goals: Review key concepts learned during the week and complete the weekly assessment.

lessons.title: Weekly Review Prep Session
lessons.learning_outcomes: We'll review key concepts and prepare for the assessment

lessons.title: Prep Lesson
lessons.learning_outcomes: Prep lesson for the weekly review

lessons.title: Weekly Review Assessment
lessons.learning_outcomes: Our weekly assessment, where you will test your knowledge from the last week using practical questions and challenges

4.learning_goal: Objects and OOP Foundations: In this unit, students will design and use interacting objects with constructors, methods, and attributes; manage lists of objects and their state over time; model one-to-one and one-to-many relationships; apply encapsulation and simple invariants to keep data consistent; and build basic inheritance and polymorphism hierarchies to choose clear, object-oriented designs.

chapters.title: Working with Objects and Relationships
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how to create and use multiple objects from a single class, read and modify their state over time, and model one-to-one and one-to-many relationships between objects using constructors, attributes, and instance methods.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Challenge II
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply constructors and instance methods to solve a small problem end-to-end; Summarize how object state is created, read, and modified in your solution

lessons.title: Review: bringing objects to life
lessons.learning_outcomes: Review how constructors, attributes, and methods work together to define object behavior; Identify and correct common mistakes in basic class designs

lessons.title: Many objects, one class
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create multiple objects from the same class with identical starting state.; Modify the state of one object without affecting the others.; Compare and interpret the state of multiple objects after different method calls.

lessons.title: Reading Object State
lessons.learning_outcomes: Read and interpret the current state of an object.; Compare the state of multiple objects and explain why their values differ.; Identify which attributes changed and which remained the same during execution.

lessons.title: Modeling relationships: one-to-one and one-to-many
lessons.learning_outcomes: Understand how to model a one-to-many relationship using objects and attributes.; Ability to decide where a relationship should be stored.; Understand how relationships affect responsibilities and state changes.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Cafe order tickets
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice designing a `CafeOrder` class with a constructor, attributes, and instance methods to manage the full lifecycle of a simple order. Output: A script that creates multiple cafe orders, prints their current state, and updates them as items are added and completed.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Library book copies
lessons.learning_outcomes: Reinforce how one class can produce many independent objects whose state changes separately over time. Output: A script that creates several `BookCopy` objects from the same class and shows how borrowing/returning affects each copy’s state independently.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Music playlist tracker
lessons.learning_outcomes: Strengthen skills in reading and comparing object state before and after method calls to explain why values differ. Output: A script that creates several `Song` objects, updates their play counts and ratings, and prints a summary comparing their final states.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Classroom and students
lessons.learning_outcomes: Model one-to-one and one-to-many relationships by linking a `Classroom` object with multiple `Student` objects and reasoning about where relationships live. Output: A script that assigns students to a classroom, prints enrollment details, and shows how adding/removing students changes both classroom and student state.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Working with Collections of Objects
chapters.learning_goals: Learn to create, store, and iterate over objects in lists; modify their state through well‑placed methods; and maintain simple invariants that keep object data valid. Practice applying these skills in small programs that produce useful, real‑world style outputs.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Working with lists of objects
lessons.learning_outcomes: Iterate over a list of objects to access their data or behavior.; Call object methods while processing a collection of objects.

lessons.title: Manipulating objects in programs
lessons.learning_outcomes: Modify object state while iterating over a list of objects.; Use object data and behavior to produce program-level results.

lessons.title: Building objects from input
lessons.learning_outcomes: Create objects using user input inside a loop.; Store created objects in a list.

lessons.title: Who owns the state?
lessons.learning_outcomes: Understand why putting logic in the right object improves clarity and reduces bugs.; Refactor a simple interaction by moving logic to a more appropriate class.

lessons.title: Simple invariants: what must always stay true
lessons.learning_outcomes: Define a simple invariant for an object and add basic checks and corrections to keep state valid over time.; Explain how invariants reduce unexpected behavior in multi-step programs.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: To-do tasks list
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice iterating over a list of objects and calling their methods to produce a meaningful overview. Output: A script that creates a list of `Task` objects and prints a formatted to‑do list with status for each task.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Fitness workout planner
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply object methods while iterating over collections to modify object state and compute program-level results. Output: A script that stores `Exercise` objects in a list, updates completed sets/reps, and prints a workout summary with total volume.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Movie night poll
lessons.learning_outcomes: Build objects from user input inside a loop and store them in a collection for later processing. Output: A script that repeatedly asks the user for movie choices, creates `MovieVote` objects, stores them in a list, and then prints a tally of votes.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Bank accounts and invariants
lessons.learning_outcomes: Strengthen understanding of putting logic in the right class and enforcing simple invariants to keep state valid. Output: A script that manages multiple `BankAccount` objects, prevents invalid balances via internal checks, and prints account summaries after several operations.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Objects, State, and Encapsulation
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how objects relate, share, and own state through references and collections, and how to design clear responsibilities between them. Practice encapsulation using getters, setters, and validation to protect object state while coordinating realistic scenarios like deliveries, study groups, user profiles, and course enrollments.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Challenge
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use relationships between multiple objects to solve a small scenario; Reflect on how invariants and ownership of state affected your design

lessons.title: Review: when objects meet
lessons.learning_outcomes: Review how objects interact through relationships and collections; Evaluate simple designs for clarity and responsibility distribution

lessons.title: Encapsulation: owning object state
lessons.learning_outcomes: Understand the principle of encapsulation, as one of the core OOP principles; Use internal attributes to store object state.; Use getter methods to read object data instead of direct access.

lessons.title: Encapsulation: protecting object state
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use setter methods to update object state.; Apply simple validation rules inside setters to prevent invalid state.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Food delivery trip
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use relationships between multiple objects (such as `Order`, `Driver`, and `Customer`) to solve a small scenario while respecting ownership of state. Output: A script that links orders to customers and a driver, simulates a delivery flow, and prints the final status of each participant.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Study group review
lessons.learning_outcomes: Review how objects interact through references and collections and evaluate simple designs for clarity and responsibility. Output: A script that models `StudyGroup` and `Student` objects, runs a short study session, and prints how many topics each student covered.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Secure user profile – Part 1
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice encapsulation by storing user data in private-like attributes and exposing getter methods instead of direct access. Output: A script that defines a `UserProfile` with hidden internal data and prints selected information using getter methods only.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Secure user profile – Part 2
lessons.learning_outcomes: Reinforce encapsulation by using setter methods with validation rules to protect and control updates to object state. Output: A script that updates `UserProfile` fields via setters, rejects invalid changes, and prints the final valid profile state.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Online course enrollment
lessons.learning_outcomes: Combine relationships, encapsulation, and invariants to coordinate `Course` and `Student` objects while keeping state consistent. Output: A script that enrolls students into courses through controlled methods, prevents invalid enrollments, and prints enrollment rosters and student schedules.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Inheritance and Polymorphism in OOP
chapters.learning_goals: Learn how to reuse and specialize behavior with inheritance, decide between composition and inheritance in real designs, and use polymorphism to write simpler, more flexible code that works uniformly with different object types.

lessons.title: Opening session and Q&A
lessons.learning_outcomes: Ask questions, clarify concepts, and engage with instructors and peers in real-time.

lessons.title: Keeping it in the family: introducing inheritance
lessons.learning_outcomes: Understand the principle of inheritance, as one of the core OOP principles; Create a subclass that inherits attributes and methods from a parent class.; Use inherited behavior on subclass objects.

lessons.title: Inheritance: sometimes kids are not like their parents
lessons.learning_outcomes: Override a method in a subclass to change behavior.; Predict which method implementation runs for a subclass object.

lessons.title: Composition vs inheritance: a practical decision rule
lessons.learning_outcomes: Explain the difference between 'has-a' and 'is-a' relationships.; Choose composition when one object should contain or use another object as a part.; Choose inheritance when one object is a specialized version of another.

lessons.title: Polymorphism basics: one action, different behaviors
lessons.learning_outcomes: Recognize polymorphism as a practical tool for simpler program logic.; Call the same method name on different object types and predict what happens.; Understand why method overriding enables different behavior under the same interface.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Zoo animals family
lessons.learning_outcomes: Apply inheritance by creating animal subclasses that reuse attributes and behavior from a base `Animal` class. Output: A script that defines several animal subclasses, creates instances, and prints shared information such as name and species using inherited methods.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Vehicle types
lessons.learning_outcomes: Practice method overriding in subclasses and predict which implementation runs for different vehicle objects. Output: A script that defines `Vehicle` and specific vehicle subclasses with overridden `describe()` or `move()` methods and prints behavior for each object.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Music app: playlist vs player
lessons.learning_outcomes: Differentiate between composition and inheritance by deciding when objects should “have” other objects versus “be” specialized versions. Output: A script that models a `MusicPlayer` that has a `Playlist` (composition) and a specialized `PremiumPlayer` that extends `MusicPlayer` (inheritance), then prints how each behaves.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Shape drawer – Part 1
lessons.learning_outcomes: Use inheritance to define a shape hierarchy and call the same method name on different shapes to observe polymorphic behavior. Output: A script that defines a `Shape` base class with subclasses like `Circle` and `Rectangle`, stores them in a list, and calls a common `area()` or `draw()` method on each.

lessons.title: Practice Lesson: Shape drawer – Part 2
lessons.learning_outcomes: Extend the polymorphic shape design to simplify program logic that processes mixed types through a shared interface. Output: A script that iterates over a list of mixed shape objects, calls the same method on each to compute totals or render output, and prints a combined summary without type-specific conditionals.

lessons.title: Closing session
lessons.learning_outcomes: Wrap up the day togeher with your peers and ask final questions

chapters.title: Weekly Review
chapters.learning_goals: Review key concepts learned during the week and complete the weekly assessment.

lessons.title: Weekly Review Prep Session
lessons.learning_outcomes: We'll review key concepts and prepare for the assessment

lessons.title: Prep Lesson
lessons.learning_outcomes: Prep lesson for the weekly review

lessons.title: Weekly Review Assessment
lessons.learning_outcomes: Our weekly assessment, where you will test your knowledge from the last week using practical questions and challenges
